Dear rxqch (hope i spelled your name correct)

[quoting JTest 4.5 help]:
To=
 have Jtest suppress errors for inputs that you do not expect to
occur, use=
 the @pre tag to specify what range of inputs is
permissible.

For example,=
 if negative inputs are not allowed, you would enter the
following comment =
above the appropriate method:
/** @pre arg >=3D0 */
[end quote]

So using t=
he '@pre' parasoft tag does not warn the developer, quite
contrary:
in the =
example quoted the parameter 'arg' is not expected to be
negative. When it =
does have a negative value, JTest will suppress
errors.

Final question for=
 rxqch:
You as a Parasoft techie should be able to determine the number of
=
runtime exceptions present in JTest version 4.5, shouldn't you ?
Why don't =
you enlighten us, or did you add tons of 'suppression' tags
?

A simple ext=
rapolation would indicate 
junit.jar, 120 Kb =3D 24 runtime exceptions
ant.=
jar, 415 Kb =3D 255 
jtest.zip, 252 --> 160 ?
jtest gui.zip, 3.148 Kb --> 1=
500 ?

yours sincerely
Arie Roy

rote:

n

lems.

 issues.

you
could

it tests.

uld be

=
to a

JTes=
t
